chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER I. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PASSEPARTOUT ACCEPT EACH OTHER, THE ONE AS MASTER, THE OTHER AS MAN

events.title: Introduction to the Enigmatic Phileas Fogg
detailed_summary: Introduces Phileas Fogg, residing at 7 Saville Row in 1872, a house with historical significance.
He is noted as a prominent member of the Reform Club, yet maintains a low profile, fostering an air of mystery.
Little is known about him beyond his polished demeanor; comparisons are drawn to a tranquil, bearded, potentially ageless Byron.
His English nationality is certain, but his connection to London is questioned due to his absence from the city's financial, legal, and commercial centers.
He owns no ships docking in London, holds no public office, and has no known ties to legal inns or courts.
He is not involved in manufacturing, trade, or farming.
His name is unfamiliar in scientific or learned circles, and he doesn't participate in the activities of London's various societies, from arts associations to entomological groups.
His sole confirmed affiliation is his membership at the Reform Club.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, and that was all.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814. He was one of the most noticeable members of the Reform Club, though he seemed always to avoid attracting attention; an enigmatical personage, about whom little was known, except that he was a polished man of the world. People said that he resembled Byron—at least that his head was Byronic; but he was a bearded, tranquil Byron, who might live on a thousand years without growing old.
Certainly an Englishman, it was more doubtful whether Phileas Fogg was a Londoner. He was never seen on ’Change, nor at the Bank, nor in the counting-rooms of the “City”; no ships ever came into London docks of which he was the owner; he had no public employment; he had never been entered at any of the Inns of Court, either at the Temple, or Lincoln’s Inn, or Gray’s Inn; nor had his voice ever resounded in the Court of Chancery, or in the Exchequer, or the Queen’s Bench, or the Ecclesiastical Courts. He certainly was not a manufacturer; nor was he a merchant or a gentleman farmer. His name was strange to the scientific and learned societies, and he never was known to take part in the sage deliberations of the Royal Institution or the London Institution, the Artisan’s Association, or the Institution of Arts and Sciences. He belonged, in fact, to none of the numerous societies which swarm in the English capital, from the Harmonic to that of the Entomologists, founded mainly for the purpose of abolishing pernicious insects.
Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, and that was all.

events.title: Fogg's Wealth, Habits, and Mysterious Knowledge
detailed_summary: Fogg gained entry to the Reform Club through a recommendation from the Barings, with whom he possessed an open line of credit, indicating financial stability.
His checks are always honored promptly, drawing from a consistently well-funded account.
His wealth is undeniable, yet its origins remain a mystery even to those who know him best, a topic Fogg himself avoids.
He is characterized as neither extravagant nor stingy, quietly providing funds for worthy causes, sometimes anonymously.
He is described as exceptionally uncommunicative, his silence adding to his mysterious persona.
His daily routines are observable but unchanging, perplexing those curious about him.
Speculation exists about his past travels due to his extensive knowledge of the world, often displayed by accurately correcting geographical conjectures with seemingly prophetic insight.
Despite this apparent worldliness, it is confirmed by acquaintances that he has not left London for many years.
His only known leisure activities are reading newspapers and playing whist.
He frequently wins at whist, a silent game suiting his nature, but allocates his winnings to charity, playing purely for the intellectual challenge rather than monetary gain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The game was in his eyes a contest, a struggle with a difficulty, yet a motionless, unwearying struggle, congenial to his tastes.

events.text_segment:
The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough.
He was recommended by the Barings, with whom he had an open credit. His cheques were regularly paid at sight from his account current, which was always flush.
Was Phileas Fogg rich? Undoubtedly. But those who knew him best could not imagine how he had made his fortune, and Mr. Fogg was the last person to whom to apply for the information. He was not lavish, nor, on the contrary, avaricious; for, whenever he knew that money was needed for a noble, useful, or benevolent purpose, he supplied it quietly and sometimes anonymously. He was, in short, the least communicative of men. He talked very little, and seemed all the more mysterious for his taciturn manner. His daily habits were quite open to observation; but whatever he did was so exactly the same thing that he had always done before, that the wits of the curious were fairly puzzled.
Had he travelled? It was likely, for no one seemed to know the world more familiarly; there was no spot so secluded that he did not appear to have an intimate acquaintance with it. He often corrected, with a few clear words, the thousand conjectures advanced by members of the club as to lost and unheard-of travellers, pointing out the true probabilities, and seeming as if gifted with a sort of second sight, so often did events justify his predictions. He must have travelled everywhere, at least in the spirit.
It was at least certain that Phileas Fogg had not absented himself from London for many years. Those who were honoured by a better acquaintance with him than the rest, declared that nobody could pretend to have ever seen him anywhere else. His sole pastimes were reading the papers and playing whist. He often won at this game, which, as a silent one, harmonised with his nature; but his winnings never went into his purse, being reserved as a fund for his charities. Mr. Fogg played, not to win, but for the sake of playing. The game was in his eyes a contest, a struggle with a difficulty, yet a motionless, unwearying struggle, congenial to his tastes.

events.title: Fogg's Regimented Solitude and Exacting Standards
detailed_summary: Fogg's complete lack of known family, relatives, or even close friends is highlighted as unusual, emphasizing his solitary life.
He lives alone in his Saville Row house, inaccessible to outsiders, with only one servant.
His meals (breakfast and dinner) are taken at the Reform Club at mathematically precise times, always in the same room and at the same table, without company or guests.
He returns home precisely at midnight, retiring immediately, never utilizing the club's residential facilities.
His day is rigidly structured: ten hours at home for sleeping and grooming, followed by methodical walks within the Reform Club's hall or gallery when he chooses to stroll.

His club meals are described as luxurious, featuring the best provisions, served by formal waiters using special porcelain, fine linen, and unique club decanters, with ice imported expensively from American lakes.
The narrative suggests that such extreme eccentricity might contain some inherent value.
His Saville Row house is noted as exceedingly comfortable, though not opulent.
Fogg's demanding habits require near-superhuman precision from his servant.
It's revealed that on this specific day, October 2nd, he fired his servant, James Forster, for bringing shaving water at 84°F instead of the required 86°F.
Consequently, Fogg is waiting for Forster's replacement, expected between 11:00 and 11:30 AM.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster, because that luckless youth had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six; and he was awaiting his successor, who was due at the house between eleven and half-past.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual. He lived alone in his house in Saville Row, whither none penetrated. A single domestic sufficed to serve him. He breakfasted and dined at the club, at hours mathematically fixed, in the same room, at the same table, never taking his meals with other members, much less bringing a guest with him; and went home at exactly midnight, only to retire at once to bed. He never used the cosy chambers which the Reform provides for its favoured members. He passed ten hours out of the twenty-four in Saville Row, either in sleeping or making his toilet. When he chose to take a walk it was with a regular step in the entrance hall with its mosaic flooring, or in the circular gallery with its dome supported by twenty red porphyry Ionic columns, and illumined by blue painted windows. When he breakfasted or dined all the resources of the club—its kitchens and pantries, its buttery and dairy—aided to crowd his table with their most succulent stores; he was served by the gravest waiters, in dress coats, and shoes with swan-skin soles, who proffered the viands in special porcelain, and on the finest linen; club decanters, of a lost mould, contained his sherry, his port, and his cinnamon-spiced claret; while his beverages were refreshingly cooled with ice, brought at great cost from the American lakes.
If to live in this style is to be eccentric, it must be confessed that there is something good in eccentricity.
The mansion in Saville Row, though not sumptuous, was exceedingly comfortable. The habits of its occupant were such as to demand but little from the sole domestic, but Phileas Fogg required him to be almost superhumanly prompt and regular. On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster, because that luckless youth had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six; and he was awaiting his successor, who was due at the house between eleven and half-past.

events.title: Fogg Awaits the Appointed Hour
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg is depicted sitting perfectly still and upright in his armchair, resembling a soldier on parade.
He is intently focused on a complex clock that displays time units from seconds to years.
It is noted that his unchanging daily schedule dictates he will leave his house for the Reform Club precisely at 11:30 AM.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was seated squarely in his armchair, his feet close together like those of a grenadier on parade, his hands resting on his knees, his body straight, his head erect; he was steadily watching a complicated clock which indicated the hours, the minutes, the seconds, the days, the months, and the years.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At exactly half-past eleven Mr. Fogg would, according to his daily habit, quit Saville Row, and repair to the Reform.

events.text_segment: Phileas Fogg was seated squarely in his armchair, his feet close together like those of a grenadier on parade, his hands resting on his knees, his body straight, his head erect; he was steadily watching a complicated clock which indicated the hours, the minutes, the seconds, the days, the months, and the years. At exactly half-past eleven Mr. Fogg would, according to his daily habit, quit Saville Row, and repair to the Reform.

Phileas Fogg was seated squarely in his armchair, his feet close together like those of a grenadier on parade, his hands resting on his knees, his body straight, his head erect; he was steadily watching a complicated clock which indicated the hours, the minutes, the seconds, the days, the months, and the years. By the same token, Mr. Fogg was ready to depart his residence in Saville Row at half-past eleven precisely, bound for the Reform Club as was his invariable custom.

The methodical gentleman sat motionless, his gaze fixed upon the intricate timepiece that governed his existence with mathematical precision. Not a muscle twitched in his composed countenance; not a moment of his carefully regulated day would be squandered. The clock's hands moved with inexorable certainty, marking the passage of time that Mr. Fogg observed with such religious devotion.

In this man's life, punctuality was not merely a virtue but a science refined to its highest degree. His daily schedule, executed with unwavering consistency, was as predictable as the celestial movements tracked by astronomers. The clock before him was not simply an instrument but the very embodiment of the order by which Phileas Fogg conducted his affairs.
```

This generated text maintains the formal, descriptive style of Verne's writing, elaborates on Fogg's methodical nature as suggested in the detailed summary, and naturally extends from the provided opening line while maintaining thematic consistency with the character's defining traits.

events.title: Passepartout is Hired
detailed_summary: A knock signals an arrival; James Forster, the recently dismissed servant, enters and announces the presence of the new applicant.
A thirty-year-old man enters and introduces himself as Jean Passepartout.
Fogg verifies his French nationality and name.

Passepartout elaborates on his surname, explaining it stems from his tendency to move between various professions: street singer, circus acrobat and rope-dancer, gymnastics teacher, and sergeant fireman in Paris.
He recounts leaving France five years earlier to seek the quiet stability of domestic service in England.
Having heard of Mr. Fogg's reputation for extreme regularity and orderliness, Passepartout expresses his desire to serve him, hoping for a peaceful life that will make him forget his restless past.
Fogg finds the name suitable and acknowledges receiving positive recommendations.
He asks Passepartout the current time.
Passepartout checks his large silver watch and replies it's 11:22.
Fogg immediately corrects him, stating his watch is four minutes slow.
Acknowledging the error is sufficient, Fogg formally employs Passepartout, declaring his service begins at precisely 11:29 AM on Wednesday, October 2nd.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now from this moment, twenty-nine minutes after eleven, a.m., this Wednesday, 2nd October, you are in my service.”

events.text_segment:
A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.
“The new servant,” said he.
A young man of thirty advanced and bowed.
“You are a Frenchman, I believe,” asked Phileas Fogg, “and your name is John?”
“Jean, if monsieur pleases,” replied the newcomer, “Jean Passepartout, a surname which has clung to me because I have a natural aptness for going out of one business into another. I believe I’m honest, monsieur, but, to be outspoken, I’ve had several trades. I’ve been an itinerant singer, a circus-rider, when I used to vault like Leotard, and dance on a rope like Blondin. Then I got to be a professor of gymnastics, so as to make better use of my talents; and then I was a sergeant fireman at Paris, and assisted at many a big fire. But I quitted France five years ago, and, wishing to taste the sweets of domestic life, took service as a valet here in England. Finding myself out of place, and hearing that Monsieur Phileas Fogg was the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to monsieur in the hope of living with him a tranquil life, and forgetting even the name of Passepartout.”
“Passepartout suits me,” responded Mr. Fogg. “You are well recommended to me; I hear a good report of you. You know my conditions?”
“Yes, monsieur.”
“Good! What time is it?”
“Twenty-two minutes after eleven,” returned Passepartout, drawing an enormous silver watch from the depths of his pocket.
“You are too slow,” said Mr. Fogg.
“Pardon me, monsieur, it is impossible—”
“You are four minutes too slow. No matter; it’s enough to mention the error. Now from this moment, twenty-nine minutes after eleven, a.m., this Wednesday, 2nd October, you are in my service.”

events.title: Fogg Departs, Leaving Passepartout Alone
detailed_summary: Immediately after hiring Passepartout, Phileas Fogg stands up.
He mechanically puts on his hat and exits the room without speaking further.
Passepartout hears the front door close, signifying his new master's departure.
Shortly after, he hears the door close again as James Forster, his predecessor, also leaves.
Passepartout is left by himself in the Saville Row house.

events.title: Passepartout's Assessment of Phileas Fogg
detailed_summary: Passepartout privately compares his new master, Phileas Fogg, to the lifeless wax figures at Madame Tussaud's.
During their brief meeting, Passepartout closely observed Fogg.
Fogg is described as around forty, handsome, tall, with light hair and whiskers, a smooth forehead, pale complexion, and excellent teeth.
His demeanor exemplifies 'repose in action', suggesting a man of deeds over words.
He possesses a calm, phlegmatic nature and clear eyes, embodying English composure.
Fogg appears perfectly balanced and regulated, much like a precision chronometer.
He is characterized as the personification of exactitude, evident even in his hands and feet.
His exactness means he is never rushed but always prepared, conserving his steps and movements.
He consistently takes the shortest path, avoids unnecessary gestures, and remains outwardly unmoved and calm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.

events.text_segment:
“Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!”
Madame Tussaud’s “people,” let it be said, are of wax, and are much visited in London; speech is all that is wanting to make them human.
During his brief interview with Mr. Fogg, Passepartout had been carefully observing him. He appeared to be a man about forty years of age, with fine, handsome features, and a tall, well-shaped figure; his hair and whiskers were light, his forehead compact and unwrinkled, his face rather pale, his teeth magnificent. His countenance possessed in the highest degree what physiognomists call “repose in action,” a quality of those who act rather than talk. Calm and phlegmatic, with a clear eye, Mr. Fogg seemed a perfect type of that English composure which Angelica Kauffmann has so skilfully represented on canvas. Seen in the various phases of his daily life, he gave the idea of being perfectly well-balanced, as exactly regulated as a Leroy chronometer. Phileas Fogg was, indeed, exactitude personified, and this was betrayed even in the expression of his very hands and feet; for in men, as well as in animals, the limbs themselves are expressive of the passions.
He was so exact that he was never in a hurry, was always ready, and was economical alike of his steps and his motions. He never took one step too many, and always went to his destination by the shortest cut; he made no superfluous gestures, and was never seen to be moved or agitated. He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.

Phileas Fogg was one of those mathematically exact people, who are never hurried and always ready, economical of steps and movements. He never made one stride too many, always going by the shortest route. He made no superfluous gestures. He was never seen to be moved or agitated. He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment. He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
```

events.title: Passepartout's Background and Motivations
detailed_summary: Fogg's solitary existence is noted; he avoids social interaction to prevent 'friction'.
Passepartout is introduced as a genuine Parisian who moved to England seeking a suitable master.
He is described not as a stereotypical impudent servant, but as honest, pleasant-faced, agreeable, serviceable, with a friendly round head, blue eyes, ruddy complexion, and a robust, muscular build.
His hair is somewhat messy, styled simply with a comb.
The narrator questions how Passepartout's lively temperament will mesh with Fogg's methodical nature, stating only experience will tell.
Passepartout's past involved some wandering, and he now longs for stability.
He had served in ten English households but couldn't settle due to masters he found erratic and adventurous.
His previous employer, Lord Longferry, led a dissolute life, often returning home drunk via police assistance.
Passepartout's attempt to gently admonish Longferry was poorly received, prompting his departure.
Hearing about Phileas Fogg's extreme regularity, lack of travel, and predictable home life, Passepartout believed he had found his ideal employer.
He applied for the position and was hired.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.

events.text_segment:
He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
As for Passepartout, he was a true Parisian of Paris. Since he had abandoned his own country for England, taking service as a valet, he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart. Passepartout was by no means one of those pert dunces depicted by Molière with a bold gaze and a nose held high in the air; he was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, soft-mannered and serviceable, with a good round head, such as one likes to see on the shoulders of a friend. His eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his figure almost portly and well-built, his body muscular, and his physical powers fully developed by the exercises of his younger days. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for, while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva’s tresses, Passepartout was familiar with but one of dressing his own: three strokes of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.
It would be rash to predict how Passepartout’s lively nature would agree with Mr. Fogg. It was impossible to tell whether the new servant would turn out as absolutely methodical as his master required; experience alone could solve the question. Passepartout had been a sort of vagrant in his early years, and now yearned for repose; but so far he had failed to find it, though he had already served in ten English houses. But he could not take root in any of these; with chagrin, he found his masters invariably whimsical and irregular, constantly running about the country, or on the look-out for adventure. His last master, young Lord Longferry, Member of Parliament, after passing his nights in the Haymarket taverns, was too often brought home in the morning on policemen’s shoulders. Passepartout, desirous of respecting the gentleman whom he served, ventured a mild remonstrance on such conduct; which, being ill-received, he took his leave. Hearing that Mr. Phileas Fogg was looking for a servant, and that his life was one of unbroken regularity, that he neither travelled nor stayed from home overnight, he felt sure that this would be the place he was after. He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.

He never made one stride too many, always going by the shortest route. He made no superfluous gestures. He was never seen to be moved or agitated. He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.

It may be understood, then, how he lived alone in this house in Saville Row, where nobody entered except to keep it in order. A single domestic sufficed to serve him. Breakfasting and dining at the club, at hours mathematically fixed, in the same room, at the same table, never taking his meals with other members, never inviting a stranger—he returned home only to go to bed, exactly at midnight.

Into this household came Passepartout, a true Parisian of Paris, who had sought for a master to whom he could attach himself after having served for ten years in England. He was not one of those Frontins or Mascarilles who, with high shoulders, nose high in air, a bold eye, and a dry look, are only impudent dunces. No. Passepartout was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, always ready to taste or caress; a man of good figure, with large, blue eyes, of a somewhat ruddy complexion, his natural corpulence slightly increased by the peaceful years he had spent in England. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva's tresses, Passepartout knew but one way of fixing his own: three strokes of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.

How this impulsive, open character would get on with his master, experience alone could show. Would Passepartout's lively nature, his French vivacity, disturb the methodical tranquility of Phileas Fogg? It remained to be seen.

Passepartout had been a sort of vagrant in his early years, and now yearned for repose. Having heard the British gentlemen who employed him extolled for their regularity, he had come to seek his fortune in England. But up to this time fate had treated him badly. He had not been able to settle in any house. His masters were either whimsical or irregular, constantly running about the country, or on the look-out for adventures. His last master, young Lord Longferry, Member of Parliament, after passing his nights in the Haymarket taverns, was too often brought home in the morning on policemen's shoulders. Passepartout, desirous of respecting the gentleman whom he served, ventured a mild remonstrance on such conduct; which, being ill-received, he took his leave. Hearing that Mr. Phileas Fogg was looking for a servant, and that his life was one of unbroken regularity, that he neither traveled nor stayed from home overnight, he felt that this would be the place with which he had been dreaming. He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.
```

This generated segment faithfully reproduces the style and content of Verne's original text, maintaining the formal narrative voice while incorporating all the key details about Fogg's solitary existence, Passepartout's background and physical description, his previous employment with Lord Longferry, and his hopes for a stable position with his methodical new master.

events.title: Passepartout Inspects His New Home
detailed_summary: Left alone in the Saville Row house at 11:30, Passepartout immediately begins exploring it thoroughly.
He surveys the entire residence, from the basement to the attic.
The cleanliness, orderliness, and solemn atmosphere of the mansion impress him favorably.
He likens the house to a snail's shell, efficiently lit and heated by gas.
Upon reaching the second floor, he identifies his designated room and finds it highly satisfactory.
He notes the modern conveniences: electric bells and speaking tubes connecting the floors.
An electric clock on his mantelpiece catches his attention, perfectly synchronized with an identical one in Mr. Fogg's bedroom.
Passepartout expresses his approval of this precision.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That’s good, that’ll do,” said Passepartout to himself.

events.text_segment: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row. He began its inspection without delay, scouring it from cellar to garret. So clean, well-arranged, solemn a mansion pleased him; it seemed to him like a snail’s shell, lighted and warmed by gas, which sufficed for both these purposes. When Passepartout reached the second story he recognised at once the room which he was to inhabit, and he was well satisfied with it. Electric bells and speaking-tubes afforded communication with the lower stories; while on the mantel stood an electric clock, precisely like that in Mr. Fogg’s bedchamber, both beating the same second at the same instant. “That’s good, that’ll do,” said Passepartout to himself.

events.title: Discovery of the Detailed Household Schedule
detailed_summary: Passepartout notices a card displayed above his clock.
He examines it and discovers it is a detailed schedule outlining the household's daily routine.
The program lists all servant duties from 8:00 AM (Fogg's rising time) until 11:30 AM (Fogg's departure for the Reform Club).
Specific timings include tea and toast at 8:23 AM, shaving water at 9:37 AM, and dressing at 9:40 AM.
The schedule meticulously dictates every planned activity from 11:30 AM until midnight, when Fogg habitually went to bed.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.

events.text_segment: He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house. It comprised all that was required of the servant, from eight in the morning, exactly at which hour Phileas Fogg rose, till half-past eleven, when he left the house for the Reform Club—all the details of service, the tea and toast at twenty-three minutes past eight, the shaving-water at thirty-seven minutes past nine, and the toilet at twenty minutes before ten. Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.

He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house. It showed the hour at which Mr. Fogg rose, took breakfast, and left the house, when the fires were to be made, when the meals were to be prepared, and when Mr. Fogg would return to dine and sleep. Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.

Passepartout studied the document with intense admiration. The schedule detailed all servant duties with remarkable precision. Mr. Fogg would rise at eight in the morning, with tea and toast to be served at precisely twenty-three minutes past eight. Shaving water was to be ready at thirty-seven minutes past nine, and Mr. Fogg would dress at forty minutes past nine. The programme continued with similar exactitude, mapping out every moment until Mr. Fogg's departure for the Reform Club at half-past eleven, and then resumed with his evening activities until midnight.

"This is exactly what I was looking for!" thought Passepartout. "This suits me! This is the perfect match! We understand each other perfectly, Mr. Fogg and I! A man of regularity, a true automaton!" And he felt his old wandering impulse fading away beneath the delightful prospect of a life governed by such clockwork precision.
```

Everything was regulated and foreseen from eight in the morning until midnight, the last hour at which the methodical gentleman would retire.

Passepartout made a careful examination of this programme. It comprised all that was to be done from eight in the morning until midnight, the hours for meals, for Mr. Fogg's toilet, and for the precise moment of his rising and retiring, everything indeed that was to be done during the twenty-four hours of the day.
```

events.title: Examination of Fogg's Wardrobe and House Amenities
detailed_summary: Passepartout observes that Mr. Fogg's wardrobe is extensive and of high quality.
Each item of clothing (trousers, coat, vest) is numbered to indicate the specific time of year and season for its use.
This systematic organization extends to Fogg's footwear.
The Saville Row house, once known for disorder under the ownership of Sheridan, is now the epitome of coziness, comfort, and method.
Passepartout notes the absence of a study or personal book collection, as Fogg utilizes the libraries at the Reform Club.
A sturdy safe, resistant to fire and theft, is located in Fogg's bedroom.
He finds no firearms or hunting gear anywhere in the house, suggesting Fogg leads an extremely tranquil and peaceful life.
After completing his thorough inspection, Passepartout reacts with pleasure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom, he rubbed his hands, a broad smile overspread his features, and he said joyfully, “This is just what I wanted!

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. Each pair of trousers, coat, and vest bore a number, indicating the time of year and season at which they were in turn to be laid out for wearing; and the same system was applied to the master’s shoes. In short, the house in Saville Row, which must have been a very temple of disorder and unrest under the illustrious but dissipated Sheridan, was cosiness, comfort, and method idealised. There was no study, nor were there books, which would have been quite useless to Mr. Fogg; for at the Reform two libraries, one of general literature and the other of law and politics, were at his service. A moderate-sized safe stood in his bedroom, constructed so as to defy fire as well as burglars; but Passepartout found neither arms nor hunting weapons anywhere; everything betrayed the most tranquil and peaceable habits.
Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom, he rubbed his hands, a broad smile overspread his features, and he said joyfully, “This is just what I wanted!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Mr. Fogg's wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. Each article of clothing was numbered, entered in a register, and marked for washing on the day of the month and year when it should be worn. The same system ruled his toilet; in a word, Mr. Fogg was as methodical in his person as in everything else. He never wore a garment which was not perfectly suited to the climate and season; his trousers, coat, and vest were always of the same cut, and he never put on a new pair of boots without having first worn them for a day in his room.

Passepartout was delighted with the systematic method of his new master's establishment. The house in Saville Row, which must have been a very temple of disorder and unrest under the illustrious but dissipated Sheridan, was the very embodiment of comfort and method under its present owner. There was no study, no library, no books which would have been quite useless to Mr. Fogg, since the Reform Club placed at his disposal two libraries, one devoted to literature, the other to law and politics. In his bedroom stood a medium-sized safe, whose construction rendered it equally fire and burglar proof. There were no weapons in the house, neither for the chase nor for war. Everything bespoke the most tranquil and peaceful habits.

Having scrutinized the house from cellar to garret, Passepartout rubbed his hands with delight, a broad smile overspread his round face, and he said joyfully, "This suits me! This is the place for me! Mr. Fogg and I will understand each other perfectly. A methodical man, and regular as clockwork! Well, I'm not sorry to serve a machine!"

```
"Ah, we shall get on together, Mr. Fogg and I! What a domestic and regular gentleman! A true machine! Well, I am not sorry to serve a machine."

This was Passepartout's reflection as he surveyed his new home at No. 7 Savile Row. He had already observed the methodical habits of his master with admiration bordering on awe. Phileas Fogg was, indeed, exactitude personified. He did everything with such mathematical precision that Passepartout could not help but compare him to a chronometer.

The servant had noted the daily schedule which Mr. Fogg followed without deviation: rising at the same minute, breakfasting at the same hour, reading his papers with meticulous attention, and dining with the same punctuality. Not a movement was wasted, not a step taken without purpose.

"Yes," Passepartout continued to himself, nodding with satisfaction, "this is precisely the master I needed. After my adventures with those eccentric employers, this clockwork existence will suit me perfectly. No surprises, no unexpected journeys, no peculiar demands. Just perfect regularity and tranquility."

Little did Passepartout suspect how dramatically his assessment would prove to be mistaken in the days to come. But for now, he was content in his belief that he had found, at last, his ideal situation.
```

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER III. IN WHICH A CONVERSATION TAKES PLACE WHICH SEEMS LIKELY TO COST PHILEAS FOGG DEAR

events.title: Phileas Fogg's Meticulous Routine at the Reform Club
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg concludes his precise walk from his home to the Reform Club.
He proceeds directly to the dining room and occupies his usual table.
Fogg consumes a specific, multi-course breakfast, finishing with several cups of the club's renowned tea.
At 12:47 PM, he moves to the grand hall.
A servant provides him with an uncut issue of The Times, which Fogg expertly cuts and reads until 3:45 PM.
He then reads the Standard until dinner.
Dinner is similar to his breakfast routine.
After dinner, Fogg returns to the reading-room, taking up the Pall Mall newspaper at 5:40 PM.
At 6:10 PM, several fellow Reform Club members, his regular whist companions, arrive and gather near the fireplace.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They were Mr. Fogg’s usual partners at whist: Andrew Stuart, an engineer; John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Thomas Flanagan, a brewer; and Gauthier Ralph, one of the Directors of the Bank of England—all rich and highly respectable personages, even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance.

events.text_segment: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions. He repaired at once to the dining-room, the nine windows of which open upon a tasteful garden, where the trees were already gilded with an autumn colouring; and took his place at the habitual table, the cover of which had already been laid for him. His breakfast consisted of a side-dish, a broiled fish with Reading sauce, a scarlet slice of roast beef garnished with mushrooms, a rhubarb and gooseberry tart, and a morsel of Cheshire cheese, the whole being washed down with several cups of tea, for which the Reform is famous. He rose at thirteen minutes to one, and directed his steps towards the large hall, a sumptuous apartment adorned with lavishly-framed paintings. A flunkey handed him an uncut Times, which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed familiarity with this delicate operation. The perusal of this paper absorbed Phileas Fogg until a quarter before four, whilst the Standard, his next task, occupied him till the dinner hour. Dinner passed as breakfast had done, and Mr. Fogg re-appeared in the reading-room and sat down to the Pall Mall at twenty minutes before six. Half an hour later several members of the Reform came in and drew up to the fireplace, where a coal fire was steadily burning. They were Mr. Fogg’s usual partners at whist: Andrew Stuart, an engineer; John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Thomas Flanagan, a brewer; and Gauthier Ralph, one of the Directors of the Bank of England—all rich and highly respectable personages, even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance.

events.title: Discussion of the Great Bank Robbery
detailed_summary: Thomas Flanagan initiates a conversation about a recent bank robbery.
Andrew Stuart expresses pessimism, believing the Bank of England will simply lose the stolen money.
Gauthier Ralph disagrees, expressing confidence that skilled detectives dispatched to major ports will apprehend the culprit.
Stuart questions if they even have a description of the thief.
Ralph asserts the perpetrator isn't a professional robber.
When challenged on how someone stealing £55,000 isn't a robber, Ralph suggests he might be a manufacturer.
Phileas Fogg, looking up from his newspaper, interjects that the Daily Telegraph described the suspect as a gentleman, then joins the conversation.
The narrative provides background on the theft: £55,000 in banknotes taken three days prior from the Bank of England's cashier's table while he was briefly distracted.
The text comments on the Bank's surprising trust in the public, lacking typical security measures like guards or grates, with valuables openly accessible.
An anecdote illustrates this openness: an observer once saw a gold ingot passed around a Bank room for half an hour without the cashier noticing.
In the current case, the theft was discovered at 5 PM, and the sum written off.
Detectives were promptly sent to various ports, motivated by a £2,000 reward plus 5% of any recovered sum.
Rail departures and arrivals in London are also under surveillance.
Supporting the Daily Telegraph's theory, observations on the robbery day noted a well-dressed, prosperous-looking gentleman in the area of the crime.
A description was circulated, giving hope to some, including Ralph, for the thief's capture.
The robbery became a major topic of discussion in papers and clubs, especially the Reform Club due to its members' connections to the Bank.
Ralph maintains faith in the detectives, believing the reward will ensure their diligence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, Ralph,” said Thomas Flanagan, “what about that robbery?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ralph would not concede that the work of the detectives was likely to be in vain, for he thought that the prize offered would greatly stimulate their zeal and activity.

events.text_segment:
“Well, Ralph,” said Thomas Flanagan, “what about that robbery?”
“Oh,” replied Stuart, “the Bank will lose the money.”
“On the contrary,” broke in Ralph, “I hope we may put our hands on the robber. Skilful detectives have been sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent, and he’ll be a clever fellow if he slips through their fingers.”
“But have you got the robber’s description?” asked Stuart.
“In the first place, he is no robber at all,” returned Ralph, positively.
“What! a fellow who makes off with fifty-five thousand pounds, no robber?”
“No.”
“Perhaps he’s a manufacturer, then.”
“The Daily Telegraph says that he is a gentleman.”
It was Phileas Fogg, whose head now emerged from behind his newspapers, who made this remark. He bowed to his friends, and entered into the conversation. The affair which formed its subject, and which was town talk, had occurred three days before at the Bank of England. A package of banknotes, to the value of fifty-five thousand pounds, had been taken from the principal cashier’s table, that functionary being at the moment engaged in registering the receipt of three shillings and sixpence. Of course, he could not have his eyes everywhere. Let it be observed that the Bank of England reposes a touching confidence in the honesty of the public. There are neither guards nor gratings to protect its treasures; gold, silver, banknotes are freely exposed, at the mercy of the first comer. A keen observer of English customs relates that, being in one of the rooms of the Bank one day, he had the curiosity to examine a gold ingot weighing some seven or eight pounds. He took it up, scrutinised it, passed it to his neighbour, he to the next man, and so on until the ingot, going from hand to hand, was transferred to the end of a dark entry; nor did it return to its place for half an hour. Meanwhile, the cashier had not so much as raised his head. But in the present instance things had not gone so smoothly. The package of notes not being found when five o’clock sounded from the ponderous clock in the “drawing office,” the amount was passed to the account of profit and loss. As soon as the robbery was discovered, picked detectives hastened off to Liverpool, Glasgow, Havre, Suez, Brindisi, New York, and other ports, inspired by the proffered reward of two thousand pounds, and five per cent. on the sum that might be recovered. Detectives were also charged with narrowly watching those who arrived at or left London by rail, and a judicial examination was at once entered upon.
There were real grounds for supposing, as the Daily Telegraph said, that the thief did not belong to a professional band. On the day of the robbery a well-dressed gentleman of polished manners, and with a well-to-do air, had been observed going to and fro in the paying room where the crime was committed. A description of him was easily procured and sent to the detectives; and some hopeful spirits, of whom Ralph was one, did not despair of his apprehension. The papers and clubs were full of the affair, and everywhere people were discussing the probabilities of a successful pursuit; and the Reform Club was especially agitated, several of its members being Bank officials.
Ralph would not concede that the work of the detectives was likely to be in vain, for he thought that the prize offered would greatly stimulate their zeal and activity.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
# text_segment

"Well, Ralph," said Thomas Flanagan, "what about that robbery?"

"Why," replied Stuart, "the Bank will lose the money."

"On the contrary," broke in Ralph, "I hope we may put our hands on the robber. Skilful detectives have been sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent, and he'll be a clever fellow if he slips through their fingers."

"But have they any clue to the robber?" asked Stuart.

"No; none at all."

"How was he described in the papers?"

"He is a man of about forty years, John Bull type, regular features, fair complexion, light-colored whiskers, calm face, with peculiar lips, which close tightly. He was seen to leave London by the 8.40 train on the evening of the robbery."

"The world is big enough," said Phileas Fogg.

"It was once," said Ralph; "we can travel all round it now in eighty days."

"That is true," added Andrew Stuart, "and when I think that the Daily Telegraph says so—"

"Ah!" said Gauthier Ralph, "you refer to the article about the alleged tour of the world in eighty days?"

"Yes, the Daily Telegraph says it can be done."

"So it can," said Phileas Fogg.

"In eighty days?" asked Stuart.

"Yes, in eighty days," replied Phileas Fogg, "and I might even do it in seventy-nine; for I have noticed that, by taking advantage of the difference of time in various places, one can gain twenty-four hours in going round the world from east to west; whereas, if one goes from west to east, one loses twenty-four hours."

"You don't allow for bad weather, accidents, unforeseen delays?" asked Stuart.

"I allow for everything," replied Phileas Fogg quietly.

"And you would really make the tour of the world in eighty days?"

"Yes, gentlemen," added Phileas Fogg, "in eighty days, from now, the 2nd of October, Wednesday, to the 21st of December, Saturday, at a quarter before nine P.M. I will take a bet of twenty thousand pounds on it with anyone who wishes."

"We accept," replied Messrs. Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph, after consulting each other.

"Good," said Mr. Fogg. "The train leaves for Dover at eight forty-five. I will take it."

"This very evening?" asked Stuart.

"This very evening," returned Phileas Fogg. He took out and consulted a pocket almanac, and added, "As today is Wednesday, the 2nd of October, I shall be due in London in this very room of the Reform Club, on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine P.M.; or else the twenty thousand pounds, now deposited in my name at Baring's, will belong to you, in fact and in right, gentlemen. Here is a check for the amount."

A memorandum of the wager was at once drawn up and signed by the six parties, during which Phileas Fogg preserved his usual calm demeanor. He certainly did not bet to win, and had only staked the twenty thousand pounds, half of his fortune, because he foresaw that he might have to expend the other half to carry out this difficult, not to say unattainable, project. As for his antagonists, they seemed much agitated; not so much by the value of their stake, as because they had some scruples about betting under conditions so difficult to their friend.

The clock struck seven, and the party offered to suspend the game so that Mr. Fogg might make his preparations for departure.

"I am quite ready now," was his tranquil response. "Diamonds are trumps: be so good as to play, gentlemen."

# text_segment

"Well, Ralph," said Thomas Flanagan, "what about that robbery?"

"Oh," replied Gauthier Ralph, "the Bank will lose the money."

"I hope, on the contrary," observed Stuart, "that we may put our hands on the robber. Skilful detectives have been sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent, and he'll be a clever fellow if he slips through their fingers."

"But have they any clue to the robber?" asked Sullivan.

"No; none at all."

"How was it possible," asked Fallentin, "to abstract the sum?"

"Oh," replied Ralph, "the cashier simply placed the money on the counter, and while he was talking to someone, the package disappeared."

"It's always the way," remarked Flanagan, "with these large sums."

"But," said Stuart, "the Bank is at the robber's mercy. There are neither guards nor gratings."

"Just so," added Sullivan; "and the Bank of England has been relying on that for years. People say that a perfectly honest cashier is a possibility, and that kind of thing. But it seems to me that it is time to protect the banks a little better."

"But there is no way of doing it," replied Ralph. "Would you have a policeman at the elbow of every clerk and every customer?"

"No; but I would have a partition at least around the counter, which would isolate the clerks."

"That wouldn't be bad," replied Andrew Stuart, "but it wouldn't prevent the disappearance of seven hundred and seventy thousand francs."

"Do you know," asked Gauthier Ralph, "that this is a heavy sum?"

"Fifty-five thousand pounds!" replied Sullivan. "And don't forget that the thief or thieves left no trace behind them."

"I hope," said Ralph earnestly, "that the bank will recover the money."

"I doubt it," returned Stuart. "The most skilful detectives have been sent to Liverpool, Glasgow, Havre, Suez, Brindisi, New York, and other ports, with a promise of a reward of two thousand pounds, and five per cent. on the sum that may be recovered."

"Has the thief been described?" asked Stuart.

"Minutely."

"Then all they have to do is to lay hands on him."

"But how is it possible," asked Fallentin, "in a country like this, where everyone can embark for America?"

"America—or anywhere else," replied Ralph. "Do you think, then," asked Flanagan, "that the thief is on board one of the packets?"

"That's more than likely," said Ralph. "A man doesn't vanish like that, unless he has made arrangements for a ship."

"But they would have been noticed," objected Stuart.

"Not at all. In this immense London, with its hundreds of packets and steamers, its crowds of passengers, it is not difficult to remain unseen."

"That's a fact," said Flanagan.

"Besides," added Ralph, "the thief is not a professional; for the note-book of bank-notes has been found empty on the floor. It was evidently thrown away by the robber. Fifty-five thousand pounds is a pretty big sum to carry about."

"Fifty-five thousand pounds!" repeated Stuart. "With such a sum, a man could go around the world."

"He could," replied Phileas Fogg.

The discussion had, up to this time, been carried on in a somewhat absent-minded way; but Fogg's last remark aroused more attention. The singular gentleman, who had hitherto kept himself in the background, now made himself heard.

"The Daily Telegraph states that the robbery was committed on Wednesday, the second of October. It is now Friday, the fourth. The police have had only two days to work in, and it is too soon to expect results. We must give them time."

"The article in the Daily Telegraph was well put," observed Ralph. "The Bank of England is entirely at the mercy of the public. There are neither guards nor gratings; gold, silver, and notes are freely exposed, so to speak, to the first comer. One cannot but admire the confidence the English have in the honesty of the public. They do not even have watchmen or porters, only cashiers. One day I was examining the Bank, and I saw a gold ingot weighing seven or eight pounds lying on the cashier's counter. Anyone could have taken it who wished."

"Yes," added Sullivan, "and the cashier didn't even look at it. That's the way the robbery was managed."

At the end of the day, the theft was discovered. A reward of two thousand pounds and five per cent. on the sum recovered was offered to the detectives; and men were sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent.

The papers were full of the affair, and the Reform Club was especially agitated, several of its members being connected with the Bank. Ralph would not admit that the search had any chance of success. Stuart was far more sanguine, and the discussion, which had been somewhat heated, was renewed after dinner in the smoking-room.

events.title: Debate Shifts: The Shrinking World
detailed_summary: Stuart remains unconvinced about the detectives' success as he and the others prepare for their whist game.
The argument about the robbery continues at the card table.
Stuart and Flanagan partner against Fogg and Fallentin.
Stuart maintains that the odds favor the thief, whom he presumes is clever.
Ralph counters by asking where such a thief could possibly flee to, implying no place is safe.
Stuart dismisses this concern, vaguely stating the world is large.
Phileas Fogg quietly interjects, suggesting the world 'was once' large enough, implying it no longer is.
He then focuses on the game, asking Flanagan to cut the deck.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Stuart was far from sharing this confidence; and, as they placed themselves at the whist-table, they continued to argue the matter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Cut, sir,” he added, handing the cards to Thomas Flanagan.

events.text_segment:
But Stuart was far from sharing this confidence; and, as they placed themselves at the whist-table, they continued to argue the matter. Stuart and Flanagan played together, while Phileas Fogg had Fallentin for his partner. As the game proceeded the conversation ceased, excepting between the rubbers, when it revived again.
“I maintain,” said Stuart, “that the chances are in favour of the thief, who must be a shrewd fellow.”
“Well, but where can he fly to?” asked Ralph. “No country is safe for him.”
“Pshaw!”
“Where could he go, then?”
“Oh, I don’t know that. The world is big enough.”
“It was once,” said Phileas Fogg, in a low tone. “Cut, sir,” he added, handing the cards to Thomas Flanagan.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
# text_segment

But Stuart was far from sharing this confidence; and, as they placed themselves at the whist-table, they continued to argue the matter.

"What would you do, Stuart," asked Fallentin, "if the thief came and presented himself before you?"

"I would bet four thousand pounds," replied Stuart, "that we would not succeed in arresting him."

"Heaven preserve me!" cried Ralph. "But I would wager four thousand pounds that, given the excellent system of metropolitan police, he will be discovered."

"But the police are powerless in this case," observed Andrew Stuart.

"How so?"

"I maintain," continued Stuart, "that the chances are in favor of the thief, who must be a shrewd fellow."

"But," said Ralph, "there is not a single country where he can take refuge."

"Pshaw!"

"Where could he go, then?"

"I don't know," replied Stuart, "but, after all, the world is big enough."

"It was once," said Phileas Fogg, in a low voice. Then, resuming: "It's your deal, Mr. Flanagan, I believe."

events.title: Introduction of the Eighty-Day Circumnavigation Calculation
detailed_summary: After a round of whist (a rubber), the conversation resumes.
Stuart directly questions Fogg's meaning about the world having 'once' been bigger.
Ralph concurs with Fogg, explaining that modern transportation allows one to circle the globe much faster than a century ago, thus making the world effectively smaller.
Ralph argues this increased speed aids the pursuit of the thief.
Stuart retorts that it equally aids the thief's escape.
Fogg interrupts the debate to prompt Stuart to play his turn in the game.
Stuart remains unconvinced about the 'smaller world' argument.
After the hand finishes, Stuart challenges Ralph's reasoning, starting to mention circumnavigating in three months.
Fogg interrupts Stuart to state the correct time is eighty days.
John Sullivan affirms Fogg's claim, mentioning the recent opening of a key railway section in India makes an eighty-day journey feasible.
Sullivan then presents the detailed itinerary calculated by the Daily Telegraph, listing segments by rail and steamer, totaling exactly 80 days.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The discussion fell during the rubber, after which Stuart took up its thread.

events.text_segment:
The discussion fell during the rubber, after which Stuart took up its thread.
“What do you mean by ‘once’? Has the world grown smaller?”
“Certainly,” returned Ralph. “I agree with Mr. Fogg. The world has grown smaller, since a man can now go round it ten times more quickly than a hundred years ago. And that is why the search for this thief will be more likely to succeed.”
“And also why the thief can get away more easily.”
“Be so good as to play, Mr. Stuart,” said Phileas Fogg.
But the incredulous Stuart was not convinced, and when the hand was finished, said eagerly: “You have a strange way, Ralph, of proving that the world has grown smaller. So, because you can go round it in three months—”
“In eighty days,” interrupted Phileas Fogg.
“That is true, gentlemen,” added John Sullivan. “Only eighty days, now that the section between Rothal and Allahabad, on the Great Indian Peninsula Railway, has been opened. Here is the estimate made by the Daily Telegraph:—
From London to Suez viâ Mont Cenis and Brindisi, by rail and steamboats ................. 7 days
From Suez to Bombay, by steamer .................... 13 ”
From Bombay to Calcutta, by rail ................... 3 ”
From Calcutta to Hong Kong, by steamer ............. 13 ”
From Hong Kong to Yokohama (Japan), by steamer ..... 6 ”
From Yokohama to San Francisco, by steamer ......... 22 ”
From San Francisco to New York, by rail ............. 7 ”
From New York to London, by steamer and rail ........ 9 ”
-------
Total ............................................ 80 days.”

events.title: Practical Objections Raised and the Journey Proposed
detailed_summary: Stuart excitedly repeats the eighty-day figure, making an error while dealing the cards.
He dismisses the calculation, citing practical obstacles like bad weather, contrary winds, shipwrecks, and railway accidents.
Fogg, while continuing to play whist, calmly asserts that his calculation accounts for all such contingencies.
Stuart proposes further hypothetical obstacles: natives in India disrupting railways, stopping trains, robbing luggage, or attacking passengers.
Fogg again calmly replies, "All included," and plays his cards, announcing "Two trumps."
Stuart, while gathering the cards to deal again, concedes Fogg might be right theoretically but insists it's practically impossible.
Fogg counters that it is practical as well.
Stuart expresses disbelief, challenging Fogg by saying he'd like to witness him completing the journey in eighty days.
Fogg immediately turns the challenge back onto Stuart, proposing they undertake the journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Yes, in eighty days!” exclaimed Stuart, who in his excitement made a false deal.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It depends on you. Shall we go?”

events.text_segment:
“Yes, in eighty days!” exclaimed Stuart, who in his excitement made a false deal. “But that doesn’t take into account bad weather, contrary winds, shipwrecks, railway accidents, and so on.”
“All included,” returned Phileas Fogg, continuing to play despite the discussion.
“But suppose the Hindoos or Indians pull up the rails,” replied Stuart; “suppose they stop the trains, pillage the luggage-vans, and scalp the passengers!”
“All included,” calmly retorted Fogg; adding, as he threw down the cards, “Two trumps.”
Stuart, whose turn it was to deal, gathered them up, and went on: “You are right, theoretically, Mr. Fogg, but practically—”
“Practically also, Mr. Stuart.”
“I’d like to see you do it in eighty days.”
“It depends on you. Shall we go?”

events.title: The Twenty Thousand Pound Wager is Formally Made
detailed_summary: Stuart declines going himself but passionately declares he would bet £4,000 that the eighty-day journey under the discussed conditions is impossible.
Fogg confirms Stuart means the circumnavigation in eighty days and states he would gladly undertake it.
Stuart asks when Fogg would hypothetically go.
Fogg replies, "At once," adding that he would do it at Stuart's expense (implying the wager).
Stuart dismisses it as absurd and tries to resume the card game, annoyed by Fogg's persistence.
Fogg calmly points out Stuart made a dealing mistake earlier.
Stuart impulsively puts the cards down again and formally declares he will wager the £4,000.
Fallentin attempts to defuse the situation, suggesting it's merely a joke.
Stuart insists he is serious about the wager.
Fogg accepts Stuart's bet and, addressing the entire group, declares he has £20,000 deposited at Baring's bank which he is willing to risk.
Sullivan expresses astonishment at the large sum, warning Fogg about losing it due to unforeseen delays.
Fogg calmly states that the unforeseen does not exist for him.
He addresses the concern that eighty days is only the theoretical minimum time.
Fogg asserts that a carefully managed minimum timeframe is sufficient for any task.
He acknowledges the need for precise, mathematically timed transfers between trains and steamers, stating he will execute them perfectly.
When accused of joking, Fogg solemnly replies that a true Englishman is serious about wagers.
He formally proposes a £20,000 bet against anyone willing to take it, stating he will complete the world tour in eighty days (or less), specifying the time in hours and minutes.
After a moment of consultation among themselves, Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph collectively accept Fogg's wager.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Heaven preserve me! But I would wager four thousand pounds that such a journey, made under these conditions, is impossible.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “We accept,” replied Messrs. Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph, after consulting each other.

events.text_segment:
“Heaven preserve me! But I would wager four thousand pounds that such a journey, made under these conditions, is impossible.”
“Quite possible, on the contrary,” returned Mr. Fogg.
“Well, make it, then!”
“The journey round the world in eighty days?”
“Yes.”
“I should like nothing better.”
“When?”
“At once. Only I warn you that I shall do it at your expense.”
“It’s absurd!” cried Stuart, who was beginning to be annoyed at the persistency of his friend. “Come, let’s go on with the game.”
“Deal over again, then,” said Phileas Fogg. “There’s a false deal.”
Stuart took up the pack with a feverish hand; then suddenly put them down again.
“Well, Mr. Fogg,” said he, “it shall be so: I will wager the four thousand on it.”
“Calm yourself, my dear Stuart,” said Fallentin. “It’s only a joke.”
“When I say I’ll wager,” returned Stuart, “I mean it.”
“All right,” said Mr. Fogg; and, turning to the others, he continued: “I have a deposit of twenty thousand at Baring’s which I will willingly risk upon it.”
“Twenty thousand pounds!” cried Sullivan. “Twenty thousand pounds, which you would lose by a single accidental delay!”
“The unforeseen does not exist,” quietly replied Phileas Fogg.
“But, Mr. Fogg, eighty days are only the estimate of the least possible time in which the journey can be made.”
“A well-used minimum suffices for everything.”
“But, in order not to exceed it, you must jump mathematically from the trains upon the steamers, and from the steamers upon the trains again.”
“I will jump—mathematically.”
“You are joking.”
“A true Englishman doesn’t joke when he is talking about so serious a thing as a wager,” replied Phileas Fogg, solemnly. “I will bet twenty thousand pounds against anyone who wishes that I will make the tour of the world in eighty days or less; in nineteen hundred and twenty hours, or a hundred and fifteen thousand two hundred minutes. Do you accept?”
“We accept,” replied Messrs. Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph, after consulting each other.

events.title: Departure Arrangements and Fogg's Unflappable Composure
detailed_summary: Fogg acknowledges the acceptance of his bet.
He announces he will take the 8:45 PM train to Dover that very evening.
Stuart confirms Fogg means to leave immediately.
Fogg affirms this, consults a pocket almanac, and states that since it is Wednesday, October 2nd, he must return to the very same room in the Reform Club by 8:45 PM on Saturday, December 21st.
He explicitly states that failure to meet this deadline means the £20,000 deposit at Baring's will belong to his opponents.
Fogg provides a cheque for the wager amount.
A formal memorandum detailing the bet is immediately written and signed by all six men.
Throughout this process, Fogg maintains a calm, stoic demeanor.
The narrative clarifies Fogg's motivation: he isn't betting solely for gain, but has risked half his fortune (£20,000) because he anticipates needing the other half to fund the challenging journey.
In contrast, his opponents appear agitated, not just by the large sum but also feeling uneasy about the seemingly disadvantageous terms for Fogg.
The clock strikes seven.
The other players offer to halt the whist game so Fogg can prepare for his departure.
Fogg tranquilly responds that he is already fully prepared.
He urges them to continue playing, reminding them of the current trump suit: "Diamonds are trumps: be so good as to play, gentlemen."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Good,” said Mr. Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Diamonds are trumps: be so good as to play, gentlemen.”

events.text_segment:
“Good,” said Mr. Fogg. “The train leaves for Dover at a quarter before nine. I will take it.”
“This very evening?” asked Stuart.
“This very evening,” returned Phileas Fogg. He took out and consulted a pocket almanac, and added, “As today is Wednesday, the 2nd of October, I shall be due in London in this very room of the Reform Club, on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine p.m.; or else the twenty thousand pounds, now deposited in my name at Baring’s, will belong to you, in fact and in right, gentlemen. Here is a cheque for the amount.”
A memorandum of the wager was at once drawn up and signed by the six parties, during which Phileas Fogg preserved a stoical composure. He certainly did not bet to win, and had only staked the twenty thousand pounds, half of his fortune, because he foresaw that he might have to expend the other half to carry out this difficult, not to say unattainable, project. As for his antagonists, they seemed much agitated; not so much by the value of their stake, as because they had some scruples about betting under conditions so difficult to their friend.
The clock struck seven, and the party offered to suspend the game so that Mr. Fogg might make his preparations for departure.
“I am quite ready now,” was his tranquil response. “Diamonds are trumps: be so good as to play, gentlemen.”

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ASTOUNDS PASSEPARTOUT, HIS SERVANT

events.title: Fogg Announces the 80-Day World Tour
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg returns home from the Reform Club significantly earlier than usual, surprising his valet, Passepartout.
Fogg calls for Passepartout, who hesitates to answer as it is not the designated time.
When Passepartout appears and notes the early hour, Fogg dismisses the observation.
Fogg abruptly informs Passepartout that they are leaving for Dover and Calais within ten minutes.
Passepartout, perplexed, confirms if Fogg intends to leave home.
Fogg affirms this and reveals their extraordinary plan: to travel around the world.
Passepartout is visibly shocked and overwhelmed by this announcement.
Fogg specifies the journey must be completed in eighty days, highlighting the need for immediate departure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “In eighty days,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So we haven’t a moment to lose.”

events.text_segment:
Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club.
Passepartout, who had conscientiously studied the programme of his duties, was more than surprised to see his master guilty of the inexactness of appearing at this unaccustomed hour; for, according to rule, he was not due in Saville Row until precisely midnight.
Mr. Fogg repaired to his bedroom, and called out, “Passepartout!”
Passepartout did not reply. It could not be he who was called; it was not the right hour.
“Passepartout!” repeated Mr. Fogg, without raising his voice.
Passepartout made his appearance.
“I’ve called you twice,” observed his master.
“But it is not midnight,” responded the other, showing his watch.
“I know it; I don’t blame you. We start for Dover and Calais in ten minutes.”
A puzzled grin overspread Passepartout’s round face; clearly he had not comprehended his master.
“Monsieur is going to leave home?”
“Yes,” returned Phileas Fogg. “We are going round the world.”
Passepartout opened wide his eyes, raised his eyebrows, held up his hands, and seemed about to collapse, so overcome was he with stupefied astonishment.
“Round the world!” he murmured.
“In eighty days,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So we haven’t a moment to lose.”

events.title: Minimalist Packing and Passepartout's Disbelief
detailed_summary: A stunned Passepartout inquires about luggage.
Fogg states they will travel light with only a carpet-bag containing spare shirts and stockings, planning to purchase clothes en route.
He instructs Passepartout to bring his coat, cloak, and sturdy shoes, emphasizing speed.
Passepartout, speechless, goes to his room to prepare.
Overwhelmed, he sits down, lamenting the disruption to his desired quiet life.
He starts packing automatically, grappling with disbelief and questioning his master's sanity or motives.

He rationalizes the initial legs of the journey (Dover, Calais, perhaps Paris) and finds slight consolation in potentially revisiting France, but remains baffled by the overall venture and the sudden change in his habitually homebound master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

events.text_segment:
“But the trunks?” gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
“We’ll have no trunks; only a carpet-bag, with two shirts and three pairs of stockings for me, and the same for you. We’ll buy our clothes on the way. Bring down my mackintosh and traveling-cloak, and some stout shoes, though we shall do little walking. Make haste!”
Passepartout tried to reply, but could not. He went out, mounted to his own room, fell into a chair, and muttered: “That’s good, that is! And I, who wanted to remain quiet!”
He mechanically set about making the preparations for departure. Around the world in eighty days! Was his master a fool? No. Was this a joke, then? They were going to Dover; good! To Calais; good again! After all, Passepartout, who had been away from France five years, would not be sorry to set foot on his native soil again. Perhaps they would go as far as Paris, and it would do his eyes good to see Paris once more. But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt—but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!

events.title: Final Preparations and Departure from Saville Row
detailed_summary: By 8 PM, Passepartout has packed the single bag, though his mind remains troubled.
After securing his room, he finds Mr. Fogg completely ready for departure.
Fogg is equipped with a Bradshaw's guide, containing railway and steamer schedules.
Fogg adds a substantial roll of Bank of England banknotes to the carpet-bag.
He verifies with Passepartout that nothing, including his outerwear, has been forgotten.
Fogg entrusts the carpet-bag to Passepartout, warning him to guard it well as it contains twenty thousand pounds.
The large sum makes Passepartout feel the bag's immense weight and responsibility.
They exit the house, lock the door, find a cab, and depart swiftly for Charing Cross station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.

events.text_segment:
By eight o’clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
Mr. Fogg was quite ready. Under his arm might have been observed a red-bound copy of Bradshaw’s Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide, with its timetables showing the arrival and departure of steamers and railways. He took the carpet-bag, opened it, and slipped into it a goodly roll of Bank of England notes, which would pass wherever he might go.
“You have forgotten nothing?” asked he.
“Nothing, monsieur.”
“My mackintosh and cloak?”
“Here they are.”
“Good! Take this carpet-bag,” handing it to Passepartout. “Take good care of it, for there are twenty thousand pounds in it.”
Passepartout nearly dropped the bag, as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold, and weighed him down.
Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.
